awd_titl_txt: Geomagnetic Variations in High Latitude Conjugate Regions
awd_abstract_narration: This project will continue research on the variations of the                    Earth's magnetic field in high latitudes in both hemispheres.                   Magnetometers are located at South Pole; McMurdo; Iqaluit, NWT,                 Canada, and Sondre Stromfjord, Greenland, with most of the                      research activity focussing on the magnetically conjugate sites of              Iqaluit and South Pole.                                                                                                                                         Specific subjects to be studied include the coupling of the                     interplanetary medium into the magnetospheric cusp regions and the              causes and propagation of low frequency hydromagnetic waves in the              magnetosphere.  A new magnetometer and data collection                          instrumentation will be installed at Iqaluit.                                                                                                                   This project is jointly supported by NSF and AT&T Bell                          Laboratories.  The grantee institution, New York City Technical                 College, is an undergraduate institution and consequently the NSF               funding is jointly provided by the Research at Undergraduate                    Institutions (RUI) program and the Division of Polar Programs.
